Sure, here are a few specific examples of how tourism has impacted the Chesapeake Bay region both positively and negatively:

Positive impacts:
- The Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum in St. Michaels, Maryland, attracts thousands of visitors each year and offers exhibits and events that celebrate the region's maritime heritage.
- The annual Chesapeake Bay Bridge Walk event, which allows participants to walk across the Chesapeake Bay Bridge, brings in tourism dollars and raises awareness about the natural beauty of the region.
- The town of Oxford, Maryland, has transformed from a mostly industrial town to a tourist destination in recent years, with restaurants, shops, and bed-and-breakfasts serving visitors who come to explore local history and take in scenic views of the Chesapeake Bay.

Negative impacts:
- In some parts of the Chesapeake Bay region, development of large hotels and resorts has led to habitat destruction, increased pollution, and negative impacts on local communities.
- The popularity of water-based activities such as fishing, boating, and swimming has resulted in overcrowding and increased pressure on natural resources in some locations.
- Some areas that were once quiet and rural have become commercialized and heavily trafficked, leading to a loss of the peaceful way of life that was once enjoyed by residents.
